content: get out your ladder your ha your trowel today we're stuck going a building
hey guys welcome back to Blackmagic
craft last week I made this little foam exposed timber building and this week I
went about doing the stucco on it or the plaster whatever you want to call it
there's quite a few different materials and techniques you can use to do this
and rather than just showing you guys the one that I chose I decided to take
this opportunity to test and demonstrate four different methods so you could find
one that is best for you and then I'll show you which one I ultimately decided
to use this is a great opportunity for me because it allowed me to try two
different techniques that I'd never tried before and ultimately one of those
techniques is what I landed on and what ended up looking really good I am so
happy with the way this technique turned out first up is the easiest and in my
opinion worst way to do plaster or stucco walls some PVA glue sprinkled
with sand it doesn't get any easier or cheaper but it also looks kind of crappy
it creates a very bumpy and grainy texture that really doesn't look
anything like plaster it looks more like large stones have been glued to the
surface of the building this is a fine method for your first build but
something I think every crafter should eventually move away from next option is
the Vallejo texture paste this is a really good option
it applies easily and quickly it's easy to control and the texture is a lot
smaller and finer than using sand and glue this stuff also dries really
quickly and quite hard making it a very good candidate the stuff when dry is
incredibly durable for the third option I tried out something that was
recommended to me in conversation by my friend Luke from Luke's ApS unsanded
tile grout this is regular gin unsanded grout that you would buy from
any hardware store it's really really cheap to buy the idea here is that
because it's basically a powder it won't leave any unnaturally large chunks like
sand and the powder itself is cement yes so once it's activated with water it
will cure quite hard his recommendation was to simply paint on some PVA or Mod
Podge to the surface and sprinkle on the powder the excess can then be shaken off
leaving only the powder that touched the glue in a very believable somewhat
smooth plaster texture if I were gonna do this method on my actual piece I
likely would add one second step of spraying down the piece with some water
and glue to hydrate any dry grout on the surface and make sure it all cured in
the end I didn't go with any of these methods they all had the same flaw they
were too thin for my building when I constructed my building I made the
Timbers about an eighth of an inch thick so they sat very proud of my foam core
structure all three of these methods were too thin to look believable and I
wanted something that would fill the area almost flush with the beams I
decided to continue on with the grout but in a way that was more in line with
how the actual material was meant to be used I mixed up some grout with water to
a fairly thin consistency almost like pancake batter I could then fill the
recesses with this mixture so that it was flush with the beams because it was
runny it would mostly self level during the test I thought it was creating too
smooth of a finish so on half of the area
I tried sprinkling on some of the dry powder to the surface to create more of
a stucco look I absolutely loved the results with my new technique in hand I
set to work applying the growth to my actual piece to do this you need to work
on one side of the building at a time and lay it flat on your work surface so
that the grout can settle when it cures this is the biggest downside to this
technique you can't bang the whole building in one go but I think
it's a worthy trade-off I was worried that it would be difficult to apply in
these smaller areas especially the ones that were triangle in shape but using a
popsicle stick it was actually really easy to work the product into the
corners once I had all of the areas filled with wet grout I went ahead and
sprinkled the dry powder over everything unfortunately this didn't result in the
same sort of texture as my test piece so I was forced to improvise and pivot I
let the grout set up for about 20 minutes
and then went to work using a flat sculpting tool to flatten all the high
areas the idea here was not to completely smooth it all out but to just
smooth the highest points and leave low areas textured which in the end created
a very believable worn plaster look I found that doing the other sides after
the one I filmed that if I left the grout to set up for even longer closer
to like an hour it was a lot easier to do this effectively the drying times
will vary depending on climate variables but in general the sweet spot is when
the grout has firmed up but not fully cured once the grout is fully cured it's
easy to go in with a brush to clean off the excess powder or an airbrush is even
better overall I'm absolutely in love with this technique it looks way better
than any of the methods I've used previously and it adds a hell of a lot
of durability to the piece all the stucco areas are now essentially 1/8
thick slabs of concrete making the walls very strong and more importantly adding
some much-needed weight to the entirely foam piece because that's one downside
to foam buildings sometimes they are almost too light so that's what I ended
up with and I'm really really happy with the results I hope you guys found this
video informative and enjoyable I hope showing the
different methods gives you a lot of good options to consider if you liked
